doc: ['Natural disaster and nuclear crisis in Japan : Response and recovery after Japan ’ s 3/11 .', 'The March 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan plunged the country into a state of crisis .', 'As the nation struggled to recover from a record breaking magnitude 9 earthquake and a tsunami that was as high as thirty-eight meter in some place , news trickled out that Fukushima had experienced meltdown in three reactor .', 'These tragic catastrophe claimed some 20,000 life , initially displacing some 500,000 people and overwhelming Japan ’ s formidable disaster preparedness.This book brings together the analysis and insight of a group of distinguished expert on Japan to examine what happened , how various institution and actor responded and what lesson can be drawn from Japan ’ s disaster .', 'The contributor , many of whom experienced the disaster first hand , assess the wide–ranging repercussion of this catastrophe and how it is already reshaping Japanese culture , politics , energy policy , and urban planning .', 'Cosmology , calendar , and horizon-based astronomy in ancient mesoamerica .', 'Cosmology , Calendars , and Horizon-Based Astronomy in Ancient Mesoamerica is an interdisciplinary tour de force that establishes the critical role astronomy played in the religious and civic life of the ancient people of Mesoamerica .', 'Providing extraordinary example of how pre-Columbian people merged idea about the cosmos with those concerning calendar and astronomy , the volume showcases the value of detailed examination of astronomical data for understanding ancient culture .', 'The volume is divided into three section : Investigation into Mesoamerican horizon-based astronomy , the cosmological principle expressed in Mesoamerican religious imagery and ritual related to astronomy , and the aspect of Mesoamerican calendar related to archaeoastronomy .', 'It also provides cutting-edge research on diverse topic such as record of calendar and horizon-based astronomical observation ( like the Dresden and Borgia codex ) , iconography of burial assemblage , architectural alignment study , urban planning , and counting or measuring device .', 'Contributors—who are among the most respected in their fields— explore new dimension in Mesoamerican timekeeping and skywatching in the Olmec , Maya , Teotihuacano , Zapotec , and Aztec culture .', 'It will be of great interest to student and scholar of anthropology , archaeology , art history , and astronomy .', 'Enablers and Barrier of Lean Implementation in Construction Projects .', 'Lean aim to maximize customer satisfaction while minimizing waste .', 'However , Lean philosophy has not been well understood yet in the construction industry for the fact that the complexity and dynamic nature of construction project bring up uncertainty that may be hardly handled by construction practitioner .', 'Moreover , project-based nature of construction business makes Lean implementation even more challenging for construction people .', 'Even though Lean effort in construction have recently increased , there are problem with the implementation processes .', 'It is undeniable that successful Lean implementation strongly affects project performance .', 'Therefore , it is essential to reveal enablers and barrier in Lean implementation so that the construction industry practitioner might conduct project more effectively and satisfy project requirement ( i.e .', 'schedule , budget , safety ) .', 'This study aims to provide a set of core enablers and barrier of Lean implementation in construction project and guide construction professional to better satisfy project requirement .', 'Within this context , the study proposes seven major enabler and barrier group , namely the financial , managerial , technical , workforce , culture , government , and communication and twenty-seven component for each group .', 'Moreover , a survey was designed and administered to Lean practitioner to rank the enablers and barrier based on importance level .', 'Clear understanding of technical requirement in Lean practice was ranked as the most important enabler of Lean implementation whereas lack of top management support was ranked as the most important barrier in the Lean implementation .', 'However , the average ranking were not found to be diverging indicating that selected component of enabler and barrier group are properly chosen .', 'The study is expected to lead Lean practitioner with creating value to customer while preventing them from experiencing waste .', 'Bridge in Urban Planning and Architectural Culture .', 'Bridge obviously serve multiple function but the primary purpose is to traverse a terrain obstacle to get good and/or people across to the other side .', 'Bridge are often viewed as an indicator of progress in technical capability , engineering skill as well as a symbol of economic potential of a particular city , region or a country .', 'Often , this is the reason why many urban bridge become the most important infrastructure in some city .', 'This paper discusses several example of bridge which have made a significant impact on the perception of a city and resulted in substantial change to landscape configuration .', 'The following available research method of evaluation were used : analysis of literature , observational in-situ study of object and own research .', 'Analysis were performed on dozen of bridge constructed over the century .', 'The example selection was directed to the well-known object , the spectacular new implementation or icon of bridge architecture .', 'The study involved both contemporary and historical object .', 'The Gateway Arch : A biography .', "Rising to a triumphant height of 630 foot , the Gateway Arch in St. Louis is a revered monument to America 's western expansion .", "Envisioned in 1947 but not completed until the mid-1960s , the arch today attracts million of tourist annually and is one of the world 's most widely recognized structure .", 'By weaving together social , political , and cultural history , historian Tracy Campbell uncovers the complicated and troubling history of the beloved structure .', 'This compelling book explores how a medley of player with widely divergent motivation ( civic pride , ambition , greed , among others ) brought the Gateway Arch to fruition , but at a price the city continues to pay .', 'Campbell dispels long-held myth and casts a provocative new light on the true origin and meaning of the Gateway Arch .', 'He shows that the monument was the scheme of shrewd city leader who sought to renew downtown St. Louis and were willing to steal an election , destroy historic building , and drive out local people and business to achieve their goal .', 'Campbell also tells the human story of the architect Eero Saarinen , whose prize-winning design brought him acclaim but also charge of plagiarism , and who never lived to see the completion of his vision .', 'As a national symbol , the Gateway Arch has a singular place in American culture , Campbell concludes , yet it also stands as an instructive example of failed urban planning .', 'Staying too long at the fair : Philadelphia planning and the debacle of 1976 .', "In 1682 , 1776 , or 1876 , the optimism of Edmund Bacon 's remarkable 1959 vision for Philadelphia 's future- '' Philadelphia in the Year 2009 '' -would have surprised no one .", "From its founding , Philadelphia 's unfolding future were consistently dynamic , focusing the energy of colonial expansion , democratic governance , and industrialization in one urban crucible .", 'No other city in America exhibited each trend so dramatically .', 'It was the Centennial Exhibition in Philadelphia in 1876- with the glass and steel dome of its Memorial Hall , its display of telegraphy and the telephone , its prototype steam automobiles-that first demonstrated to Americans what an industrialized nation might really look like .', "Ed Bacon was an enthusiast of world 's fair and public exhibition , writing and speaking of them throughout his career to illustrate and promote trend in urban development , and working in the genre himself to advance a far-reaching planning agenda for Philadelphia in the postwar decade .", 'Philadelphia emerged from World War II burdened by creaking infrastructure and a housing shortage , its Center City business district underperforming against rival city .', "Deindustrialization was already noticeable by the mid-1950s , an emerging economic reality that foretold difficulty in achieving the social goal of a new and aggressive generation of reform-minded political leadership.1 Resident were embarking for the suburbs at a steady clip , with the city falling by 1960 from third to fourth in population behind Los Angeles.2 Bacon 's 50-year vision projected against this backdrop might have struck the reader as cheerful but unrealistic , even naïve .", 'But what good is a prophecy if it does not reveal a hidden future , a future obstructed ?', "Bacon 's future was a city revitalized , beautified , and modernized in time to host the nation 's Bicentennial celebration and a simultaneous 1976 Philadelphia World 's Fair .", "Imaginative planning was his method , enabling the political gatekeeper along with the citizen of the city to see with him decade ahead and to grasp the occasion of a fair to accomplish lasting change for the city 's built environment and its people .", "`` Philadelphia in the Year 2009 '' builds its case on this one powerful idea : A world 's fair could transform it into a model of humane urbanism.3 Considering his vantage point in 1959 , it is possible to imagine why Ed Bacon might predict the future of Philadelphia with such mesmerizing flourish .", 'The Philadelphia City Planning Commission ( PCPC ) , under his directorship , was in the midst of one of the longest winning streak any urban planning body had or has ever achieved .', 'With Penn Center , Society Hill , Independence Mall , the neighborhood of Eastwick and the Far Northeast each underway or finished , Bacon and his team of young planner were totally in their stride in 1959 , working to think , dig , and build the city out of its rut .', "The Market East transportation center , a pedestrian-friendly Chestnut Street , and a tourist-friendly Delaware waterfront were all on Bacon 's drawing board , too .", 'These were the varied piece , described in turn by each of the author in this volume , of a full urban-renewal portfolio advanced consistently over more than two decade by the PCPC .', "Postwar federal legislation enabled city official for the first time to broadly exercise eminent domain power , moving mass of resident and bulldozing whole section of the city , planning and building anew.4 Ed Bacon 's PCPC was certainly of its time in this respect and forceful in its place , stirring up both wonder and backlash .", 'The old industrial city , the city that had lain fallow through the Depression and World War II , was awakening slowly to the possibility of highrises and integrated transportation hub , and at the same time rediscovering its walkable character and the vernacular beauty of its historic neighborhood .', "Bacon 's idea was to liberate William Penn 's grid from over a century of industrial-age clutter and to make the city simultaneously auto- , pedestrian- , and investment-friendly .", 'Bacon understood the power of display and salesmanship as key to making his idea of the next Philadelphia into something tangible .', "In this spirit , his `` 2009 '' essay arrived on newsstand in 1959 .", 'Could new high-rise and a suburban-style shopping center downtown reverse massive job loss and a suburban exodus ?', "Whether the PCPC 's project were comprehensive enough remained an open question in 1959 .", "In this context , the Philadelphia World 's Fair could provide a shared goal , a focused way for Bacon to complete the project he wanted .", "Market East , the Chestnut Street pedestrian mall , and even the heliport and Kabuki dancer really pale in comparison , though , to his essay 's boldest claim .", 'In 2009 Philadelphia will not have any bad neighborhood , suburbanite will have moved back bringing their vitality and tax dollar with them , greenway will ring the city , transportation option will be rational and varied ; the entire metropolis will reflect the best and brightest idea that modern urban planning can deliver .', "Bacon 's prediction still astound with their self-confidence , and throughout the 1960s and into the 1970s , from City Hall to the hall of academia and elite architecture firm and banker ' office , from newsroom to neighborhood across the city , Philadelphians would grapple with the idea that a world 's fair could help deliver the future city they desired .", 'This chapter examines the fair-as-urban renewal formula that Ed Bacon worked with to promote his long-range planning objective in Philadelphia .', "The `` 2009 '' essay was just one of the many publication and speech he used to stimulate and sustain interest in the manifold project of the PCPC .", 'But here was a truly seductive model of development .', "If a world 's fair could leave useful permanent structure behind while simultaneously rejuvenating public faith in the city , then what was the downside ?", 'Ed Bacon and score of Philadelphians would take up this challenge , shaping it over a 15-year period to fit their own vision for the future of their city .', "From London 's 1851 Crystal Palace Exhibition to New York 's 1939 World 's Fair , such event periodically announced new era in technology and science , in business , and in culture .", 'As Bacon and other key player in Philadelphia intuited , they also offered host city opportunities to innovate in urban design .', "Starting with Brussels in 1958 a new generation of postwar world 's fair began , and the planning for the Philadelphia Fair took place as fair were held in Seattle ( 1962 ) , New York ( 1964 ) , Montreal ( 1967 ) , San Antonio ( 1968 ) , and Osaka ( 1970 ) .", 'The difficulty of the New York Fair and the success of the Montreal one especially played defining role as the Philadelphia planning process went forward .', "Learning and applying lesson from fair in other city and other era proved difficult for Philadelphia 's planner .", 'The chapter develops two main analytical point .', "First , world 's fair have historically proven as different and mercurial as the city and time period of their creation , and have rarely inspired large-scale urban renewal in host city in predictable , linear way .", "The historical lesson and legacy of world 's fair for urban planner were ( and remain ) decidedly ambiguous .", 'But by studying the period of gestation for a fair , and perhaps by extension any large-scale civic undertaking , we gain critical insight into the dominant conflict shaping the modern city .', "As the planning process moved into the 1960s and early 1970s , it became more and more evident that the Philadelphia World 's Fair of 1976-if it was to happen-would not recreate the 1876 Centennial Exhibition or launch an urban renaissance so much as reflect the clashing ambition of citizen caught in a declining American industrial metropolis .", "The final plan , to the extent there ever was one plan , deviated starkly in both intention and design from Bacon 's 1959 vision .", 'This leads to the second point .', "The deviation from Bacon 's `` 2009 '' vision shows two quite specific urban historical process working in conjunction : The decline of the `` master planner '' and by extension New Deal/Great Society urban liberalism , and the rise of a consensus-seeking planning model driven by the maturation of urban community-based protest movement .", "The evolving plan for the World 's Fair vividly show these trend defining one another , with plan for ( and protest against ) the Fair emerging from all quarter of the city , diluting the strength of Bacon 's 1959 vision , while at the same time adding element more desirable , more democratic , to the multiple community affected .", 'Between 1970 and 1972 planning for the Fair broke apart amid a prolonged season of racial strife , intergenerational resentment , federal disinvestment , and a creeping urban pessimism .', 'Combined with hesitant municipal leadership this climate of urban uncertainty clouded the vision of a fair-as-catalyst to a utopian `` Philadelphia in the Year 2009 .', '`` .', 'The 1876 centennial in Philadelphia : Elite network and political culture .', 'AT NOON on May 10 , 1876-after year of controversy , construction , and fuss-President Ulysses S. Grant and Emperor Dom Pedro of Brazil entered Machinery Hall to open the Centennial Exhibition of 1876 in Philadelphia .', "Since early morning , the day 's 186,000 attendee had been streaming through the gate .", 'The president and the emperor stood in front of thirteen acre of motionless machinery , all connected by pulley , shaft , wheel and belt to the giant Corliss engine in the central transept .', 'Several hundred invited guest , already waiting there , made room for the ceremonial party to climb upon the concrete base of the huge metal monster towering forty foot above their head almost to the trussed roof of the Hall .', 'Machinery Hall was one of five major building put up by exhibition organizer in Fairmount Park ; outside group built dozen more .', 'The Main Building was the largest in the world at the time-over a third of a mile long .', "Visitor marveled at the item on display : A typewriter , Hires root beer , the Statue of Liberty 's torch , the Westinghouse air brake , Fleischmann 's yeast , cable from the Brooklyn Bridge , Bell 's telephone , and Otis 's elevator.2 The Centennial was a resounding success , dramatically displaying Philadelphia 's wealth and industrial might .", "Over nine million people-nearly one-fifth of the country 's population-attended before its close in November .", 'It was the first international exposition held in the United States and probably the single most important cultural event of its era .', "Foreigner flocked to Philadelphia-inaugurating mass tourism to the United States-to see American industrial innovation and dozen of foreign exhibit from Britain , Norway , Belgium , Russia , Japan , China , Sweden , Germany , France , Italy , Canada , Mexico , Brazil , and `` two large Arab tent . ''", "This influx of visitor and national culture also opened Philadelphia andthe United States to a world of new influence ; the Japanese exhibit in particular stirred an Oriental design fashion in the United States.3 Beyond the pomp , the fanfare , the hotel receipt , and the visitor , the Centennial also helped restructure the city 's politics .", 'The event both cemented network of alliance among previously divided elite and marked the ascendance of a Republican hegemony in local political culture that would be virtually unchallenged for the next sixty year .', "The Republican regime that coalesced in the 1870s combined several element : party bossism centered in control of several city agency , an electoral machine that came to trade vote for public construction contract , business support based in ideological solidarity ( support for protectionist legislation ) , and reliance on rail- And port-related industry as the engine of the city 's economy .", "In Philadelphia 's case , the irony is that those Republicans who did the most to make the Centennial happen-large , reformist civic organization like the Union League that played crucial role in event planning and in promoting commitment to the Republican Party-did not necessarily enjoy the political fruit of their labor .", "Over time , the elite 's cultural and ideological commitment to Republicanism became a straitjacket , and they lost control of the polity they had helped build .", 'More broadly , I use the example of the Centennial to examine the role that cultural project play in urban governance .', 'These project , and the planning effort that produce them , contribute to the emergence and consolidation of governing regime out of situation of extreme political discord and fragmentation .', 'They connect process of elite network formation ( social capital ) and ideological consolidation .', "These two process in turn are the building block of hegemony in local governance-cultural and social leadership that shapes people 's political commitment and the extent to which they are willing to consider or pursue alternative to prevailing arrangement .", 'Promptness and sustainability in town reconstruction following the 2011 great east Japan earthquake .', 'Local government in Iwate Prefecture also drew respective plan for reconstruction to rebuild their city , financially backed up by the prefectural and national government coupled with special law and measure .', 'They are planning central city area under the principle of DRR as well as BBB .', 'There are too many law pertaining to disaster prevention and reconstruction to refer to in full here .', 'Therefore , this chapter focuses only on some of the new enactment after the GEJE .', 'But attention has to be paid to their approach to reconstruction when it comes to the question of whether they sufficiently concord with DRR and BBB ( Ikuta 2013 ; Kaneko 2014 ) .', 'The Basic Act on Reconstruction in Response to the GEJE 2011 ( hereinafter the Basic Act 2011 ) prescribes that , considering the unprecedented national crisis caused by the GEJE , the act has the purpose of promoting the smooth and prompt reconstruction and revitalization of a vibrant Japan , securing financial resource , identifying afflicted area as Special Zone for Reconstruction with institutional and tax measure and establishing a Reconstruction Agency to undertake task regarding integrated national measure ( Art .', '1 ) .', 'The Basic Act 2011 then prescribes its basic philosophy , adopting the idea of the building back better concept , promoting dramatic measure for revitalization that are not limited to physical recovery of afflicted facility , but also reconstruction measure to assist individual to overcome the disaster and lead prosperous life while honoring local culture and enhancing people ’ s tie with the community ( Art .', '2 ) .', 'The Act for Special Zones for Reconstruction 2011 was enacted as separate legislation from the Basic Act 2011 to implement the reconstruction measure .', 'Under this legislation , afflicted local government designated as special area can acquire significantly larger budget fund from the national government for recovery and can deregulate their spatial planning under the Agricultural Land Act , the Forest Act and the Urban Planning Act .', 'Via this funding and deregulation , they can plan recovery-related project for disaster prevention : the promotion of collective relocation , functional reinforcement of fishery village , land reallocation for the revival of affected city area , basic construction to lead city center towards recovery from the tsunami and disaster-resistant public housing .', 'The Act on Town Planning for Tsunami Disaster Prevention 2011 allows prefectural government to set tsunami hazard zone and municipal government to make integrated town plan for tsunami disaster prevention .', 'Under the act , prefectural government can set the presumed tsunami hazard zone and special tsunami warning zone .', 'In the latter zone , normal town planning and building activity are restricted .', 'Change management project .', "Construction manager are not just concerned with on-site construction project but also involved in many `` Change Management Projects '' .", 'The importance for accepting the cultural dimension of Change Management Projects were established in the following section : cultural dimension , culture as a context , organization as culture , culture and identity , environmental culture organizational culture , culture and project management , and lastly , influencing and persuading the project team .', 'In general , a consistent approach to managing people and cultural change is the mark of a good project manager .', 'North Americas first civil engineer construct seventh century suspension bridge at yaxchilan .', "A millennium before Europeans reached the Americas , the Maya had developed one of the world 's longest lasting civilization .", 'This society reached its peak during the classic period , which extended from 250 BC to 900 AD .', 'During their 2000-year history , the Maya held domain over a powerful Empire ruled by City States .', 'The Maya Empire established a scientifically based culture while Europe languished in the Dark Ages .', 'During their classic period , the Maya developed numerous scientific and engineering advancement .', 'These ingenious people developed a mathematical system that recognized the concept of the number zero seven hundred year before the Europeans ; a calendar system that is more advanced than our current calendar ; ingenious engineering application including manufacturing of cement , clear span cast-in-place concrete structure ; and a complex infrastructure that served the need of their sophisticated and highly populated ceremonial urban center .', 'Around 700 AD the Maya achieved an exceptional feat in civil engineering history with the construction of a long-span suspension bridge across the Usumacinta River at the ceremonial center at Yaxchilan .', 'The 63 meter center span was the longest in the world until Italian engineer constructed a 76 meter bridge over the Adda River in northern Italy in 1377 .']

["'Our tyne ' : Iconic regeneration and the revitalisation of identity in NewcastleGateshead .", 'The landscape of the north-east of England , both urban and rural , is perhaps most notable as a deindustrialised landscape .', 'Indeed , the world in which we live is determined as much by what it was as by what it is .', 'Perhaps this is no more evident than in the case of NewcastleGateshead which is often portrayed as an exemplar of the revitalising benefit of culture-led regeneration .', 'The , as yet unproven , success of NewcastleGateshead Quayside is founded upon a massive financial investment in iconic project .', 'But under what condition is , if at all , such iconography succeeding ?', 'This article addresses the impact of flagship regeneration project and their role in radically rearticulating the meaning of place and space in a so-called post-industrial world .', "It is suggested that the success of investment in iconic cultural project depends above all upon people 's sense of belonging in a place and the degree to which cultureled regeneration can engage with that sense of belonging , whilst balancing achievement of the past with ambition for the future .", 'The place of alternative culture and the politics of its protection in Berlin , Amsterdam and Melbourne .', 'At the same time as changing global political-economies of land use are displacing low-income people from inner city , countering socio-cultural force are inspiring marginal community to resist .', 'This article focuses on the loss of place used by alternative culture in the inner city , and the effect of their claim to a right to the city and to difference .', 'Some city are turning to their planning and heritage system to protect the place of alternative culture , but unexamined use of these strategy can cause as many problem as they solve .', 'The article considers some more reflective response from three city government that can not afford to lose the symbolic capital of their ( sub ) cultural economy .', 'Transcultural city : Border-crossing and placemaking .', 'Transcultural Cities uses a framework of transcultural placemaking , cross-disciplinary inquiry and transnational focus to examine a collection of case study around the world , presented by a multidisciplinary group of scholar and activist in architecture , urban planning , urban study , art , environmental psychology , geography , political science , and social work .', 'The book addresses the intercultural exchange as well as the cultural trans-formation that takes place in urban space .', "In doing so , it views culture not in isolation from each other in today 's diverse urban environment , but as mutually influenced , constituted and transformed .", 'In city and region around the globe , migration of people have continued to shape the makeup and making of neighborhood , district , and community .', 'For instance , in North America , new immigrant have revitalized many of the decaying urban landscape , creating renewed cultural ambiance and economic network that transcend border .', 'In Richmond , BC Canada , an Asian night market has become a major cultural event that draws visitor throughout the region and across the US and Canadian border .', 'Across the Pacific , foreign domestic worker in Hong Kong transform the deserted office district in Central on weekend into a carnivalesque site .', 'While contributing to the multicultural vibe in city , migration and movement have also resulted in tension , competition , and clash of culture between different ethnic community , old-timer , newcomer , employee and employer , individual and institution .', "In Transcultural Cities Jeffrey Hou and a cross-disciplinary team of author argue for a more critical and open approach that sees today 's city , urban place , and placemaking as vehicle for cross-cultural understanding .", 'Dominican-americans and the politics of empowerment .', 'Aparicio examines the way first- and second-generation Dominican-americans in the dynamic northern Manhattan neighborhood of Washington Heights have shaped a new Dominican presence in local New York City politics .', 'Through community organizing , they have formed coalition with people of different national and ethnic background and other people of color , tackled local concern , and created new route for empowerment .', 'The character of Dominican-American politics has changed since the first large wave of Dominican immigrant arrived in New York in the 1960s .', 'Aparicio shows how second-generation activist , raised and educated in public institution in the city , have expanded their network to include fellow Dominicans-both in the United States and abroad -- as well as other ethnic and racial minority , such as Puerto Ricans and African-Americans , who share common goal .', 'Offering the perspective of local organizer and member of Dominican-American organization , Aparicio document their thought on such issue as education , police brutality , civic participation , and politics .', 'She also explores the way in which they experience , reflect upon , and organize around issue of race and racialization process , and how their experience influence their political agenda and action .', "This new story of immigration and empowerment highlight the complexity of any group 's political development , making it useful for student of U.S. Latino and youth culture , as well as scholar of urban study and politics , race , immigration , and transnationalism .", 'An ( Extra ) ordinary Night Out : Urban Informality , Social Sustainability and the Night-time Economy .', 'A night out in the metropolis can offer a plethora of hedonistic experience in urban space such as waterfront district , shopping boulevard and cultural precinct .', 'In stark contrast to this post-modern spectacle of contemporary nightlife are the mundane night-time activity that pervade the everyday space of ordinary people .', 'Here , we are confronted with a tapestry of a different material culture-one that has evaded the lacklustre and homogeneous pattern of urban bar , pub and club .', 'This paper will illuminate the sociospatial dimension of everyday ( night ) life in the neighbourhood of Toa Payoh Central , Singapore , and will demonstrate the resilience of urban informality in an increasingly formal and regulated global city like Singapore .', 'It is contended that everyday ( night ) life has a significant role to play in the making of vibrant and liveable city by helping to foster social sustainability in the form of accessibility , tolerance , diversity and participation .', 'Urban planning and cultural identity .', 'Urban Planning and Cultural Identity reviews the intense spatiality of conflict over identity construction in three city where culture and place identity are not just post-modernist plaything but touch on the raw sensibility of who people define themselves to be .', "Berlin as the reborn German capital has put 'coming to term with ' the Holocaust and the memory of the GDR full square at the centre of urban planning .", 'Detroit raises question about the impotence and complicity of planner in the face of the most extreme metropolitan spatial apartheid in the United States and where African-American identity now seems set on a separatist course .', "In Belfast , in the clash of Irish nationalist and Ulster unionist tradition , place can take on intense emotional meaning in relation to which planner as 'mediators of space ' can seem ill equipped .", 'The book , drawing on extensive interview source in the case study city , poses a question of broad relevance .', 'Can planner fashion a role in using environmental concern such as Local Agenda 21 as a vehicle of building a sense of common citizenship in which cultural difference can embed itself ?', 'Neill .', 'Culture is reclaiming the creative city : The case of Macao in Milan , Italy .', 'In May 5 , 2012 , a group of artist and cultural worker occupied a 33-storeys abandoned skyscraper in Milan , founding Macao or the “ New Centre for Arts , Culture and Research ” .', 'It was an event , with thousand of people joining in , newspaper headline , and a massive flow of social medium activity .', 'Along with space , they claimed a new role for art and culture in society .', 'Macao constitutes one of the last node of the national network of occupied theatre , which spread out in Italy from early 2011 .', 'This case is explored with the aim of understanding to what extent Macao , and more in general the global wave of art activism , constitutes an alternative to the neo-libel articulation of the creative city in Milan .', 'On the one hand , we ask whether Macao is a political actor able to influence the local cultural policy and to what extent it is included in the urban governance of Milan .', 'Related question concern Macao claim and expectancy , and its possible process of normalization .', "On the other hand , we evaluate Macao 's role into the cultural milieu at different level ( local , national , international ) .", 'We will argue that Macao not only is an actor included in the urban governance , but also it provides the city a different cultural offer , open to bottom-up process .', 'Semi-detached empire : Suburbia and the colonization of Britain , 1880 to the present .', "In the first book to consider British suburban literature from the vantage point of imperial and postcolonial study , Todd Kuchta argues that suburban identity is tied to the empire 's rise and fall .", 'He takes his title from the type of home synonymous with suburbia .', 'Like the semi-detached house , which joins separate dwelling under one roof , suburbia and empire were geographically distinct but imaginatively linked .', "Yet just as the `` semi '' conceals two home behind a single façade , suburbia 's apparent uniformity masks its defining oppositions-between country and city , `` civilization '' and `` savagery , '' master and slave .", 'While some people saw the suburbs as homegrown colony , others viewed them as a terra incognita beyond the pale of British culture .', "Surveying a range of popular and canonical texts , Kuchta reveals the suburban foundation of a variety of unexpected fictional locale : the Thames Valley of H. G. Wells 's Martian attack and the gaslit London of Arthur Conan Doyle 's Sherlock Holmes , but also the tropical backwater of Joseph Conrad 's Malay Archipelago and the imperial community of Raj fiction by E. M. Forster and George Orwell .", "This capacious view demonstrates suburbia 's vital role in science fiction , detective tale , condition-of-England novel , modernist narrative of imperial decline , and contemporary multicultural fiction .", 'Drawing on postcolonial theory , urban study , and architectural scholarship , this book will appeal to reader interested in Victorian , modern , and contemporary British literature and culture , especially those concerned with how place shapes class and masculine identity in the nineteenth and twentieth century .', 'Urban beautification : The construction of a new identity in Chicago .', 'DURING THE LAST 20 YEARS , cultural policy has become an integral part of economic and physical redevelopment strategy for many urban center across the United States .', 'Driven by deindustrialization , population decentralization , and globalization , many city have turned to cultural strategy as a means to reposition themselves in a rapidly changing economic environment or to reaffirm their standing in an evolving metropolitan hierarchy .', 'One factor fueling culture-driven strategy in urban development is that citizen now have more leisure-expendable income than ever before .', 'This fact has led city government to increase expenditure on culture and related specialized bureaucracy .', 'As a result , policymaking body have ventured to enhance their provision of cultural service to cater to a growing , more differentiated , and increasingly sophisticated public demand .', 'The outcome of these trend has resulted in the development of an economy of urban tourism .', 'This has encouraged city and their government to turn their attention to policy that center on showcasing their cultural heritage , exporting their cultural identity , and translating these policy into revenue stream that can then be used for social and economic transformation .', 'Hence , promoting festival , art , sport , music , cinema , convention , and exhibits has come to be viewed as central activity of this strategy .', 'This trend is the focus of an April 2000 report published by the National League of Cities entitled Tourism and Entertainment as a Local Economic Development Strategy : A Survey of City Halls ( Judd et al .', '2000 ) , which discusses how tourist and entertainment infrastructure has recently emerged as a primary form of public investment in American city .', 'How has this tourism-focused economic restructuring come to fuel emerging urban-planning strategy ?', 'Although there is no simple answer to this question , multiple issue can be identified as factor that have caused the ascendance of urban tourism and associated public works activity .', 'In the past , tourism and related cultural form did not fit the planning mix and were viewed at best as inconsequential element of local economic activity ( Beauregard 1998 ) .', 'The motivation and rising demand for urban tourism may be found in two fundamental factor .', "The first can be drawn from a recent and continuing desire by people to explore the unfamiliar and to construct or to solidify their identity through travel and appropriately utilized leisure time ( Law 2002 ) .Whether it is the search for self- Actualization ( Maslow 1970 ) , the acquisition of `` cultural capital '' ( Bourdieu 1984 ) , or identity formation through consumption ( Baudrillard 1988 ) and pilgrimage to famous place ( MacCannell 1976 ) , or even the `` tourist gaze '' as projected onto destination by the medium ( Urry 1990 ) , tourism and leisure activity have entered and influenced the realm of human experience in way more powerful and profound than ever before .", 'The second factor relates more directly to the dynamic of city governance and to the contemporary condition of city .', 'The economic decline following the post war restructuring ; the impact of globalization , which substantially reduced the primacy of the U.S. economy in production activity ; and diminishing contribution by the federal government to the city and state , presented a series of challenge for local official facing the new fiscal reality of shrinking budget and service .', 'City responded by divorcing themselves from their manufacturing dependency ; instead , they searched for way to diversify and strengthen the various remaining sector of their economy .', 'Within this framework , urban tourism emerges as an appealing alternative , one that slowly has gained favor with local official and civic booster alike .', 'As city rush to take advantage of this new growth potential , they face numerous challenge , mainly in the area of urban identity and urban competition .', 'Specifically , how can a city with a formerly strong and nationally or internationally identifiable manufacturing economy convert itself intoa tourist destination ?', "Most important , how does it convince potential visitor of its new service and sense of `` attractiveness '' ?", 'Similarly , what are its competitive advantage within this reformulated environment ?', 'The rise of urban tourism increase intermunicipal competition and requires city to be more entrepreneurial .', 'In Marketing Place : Attracting Investment , Industry , and Tourism to Cities , States , and Nations , international marketing guru Philip Kotler along with Donald H. Haider and Irving Rein ( 1993 ) definitively make the point that competition is a new reality that can not be avoided : `` Place have to visualize a clearer sense of the function they perform and the role they play .', '.', '.', '.', "A place that fails to examine its prospect and potential critically is likely to lose out to more attractive competitor '' ( p. 311 ) .", 'Within this context , the city is no different from the corporation that must engage in image-building activity , market its product , and be prepared to deal with change if it wants to maintain its competitive edge .', 'The competition to attract tourist has had a tremendous impact on city as spatial transformation , increased commodification , rapid segmentation of urban form and function , and new economic and planning mechanism became widely introduced .', "The `` tourist bubble '' has emerged as a commonrestructuring strategy ( Judd 2003 ; Judd and Fainstein 1999 ) .", 'Convention center , theme park , stadium , and casino and riverboat gambling have reshaped the physical landscape and image of hundred of dying urban core .', 'The city of leisure and entertainment , aimed at attracting local and visitor , has caused a reorganization of planning policy and priority ( Clark 2003 ; Spirou and Bennett 2003 , 37-58 ) .', 'City , cultural policy and governance .', 'Today is a new metropolitan age and for the first time ever more people live in city than they do anywhere else .', "As city strengthen their international and cultural influence , the global world is acted out most articulately in the world 's urban hubs - through its diverse culture , broad network and innovative style of governance .", 'Looking at the city through its internal dynamic , the book examines how governance and cultural policy play out in a national and international framework .', 'Making a truly global contribution to the literature , editor Isar and Anheier bring together a truly international and highly-respected collection of scholar .', "In doing so , they skilfully steer debate beyond the city as an economic powerhouse , to cover issue that fully comprehend a city 's cultural dynamic and its impact on policy including alternative economy , creativity , migration , diversity , sustainability , education and urban planning .", 'Innovative in its approach and content , this book is ideal for student , scholar and researcher interested in sociology , urban study , cultural study , and public policy .', "Dance and wellbeing in Vancouver 's ‘ A Healthy City for All ’ .", 'Through the lens of the dancing body , this paper examines practice of health and wellbeing produced in response to City of Vancouver urban governance policy .', 'In particular , it calls attention to the legislative onslaught by city government in the year abutting the 2010 Winter Olympics to cultivate and manage healthy people , community , and environment .', "In an effort to sell Vancouver 's ‘ liveability ’ , I argue City of Vancouver endorsed a new legislative alliance that merged a conspicuously Anglo-American wellbeing lexicon , favouring individual responsibility and self-governance , with the performing art industry .", "Drawing upon interview and performance-based research , the paper illustrates how Karen Jamieson 's community dance project Connect , created for the In the Heart of the City festival , embodies Vancouver 's tri-level legislative ambition to nurture A Healthy City For All .", 'This materialised through the crafting of a dance-health body practice ( healthy people ) , by choreographing a sense of belonging among ‘ at risk ’ community ( healthy community ) , and in the uniting of the art and health profession in the process of ‘ cleaning up ’ disenfranchised neighbourhood ( healthy environment ) .', 'In bringing together scholarship on culture of wellbeing and creative dance practice , the article contributes to understanding of how the health-seeking subject is embodied and performed .', 'It also offers a productive critique of the exclusionary nature of urban health legislation , and of the contested role artist and art festival can play in nurturing urban wellbeing and normalising inequality .', "Urban music and entrepreneurship : Beat , rhyme and young people 's enterprise .", 'Youth unemployment in the UK remains around the one million mark , with many young people from impoverished background becoming and remaining NEET ( Not in Education , Employment , or Training ) .', 'However , the NEET categorisation covertly disguises and obscures the significance of the diverse range of activity , achievement and accomplishment of those who operate in the informal creative economy .', 'With grime music and its related enterprise a key component of the urban music economy , this book employs the inherent contradiction and question that emerge from an exploration of the grime music scene to build a complex reading of the socio-economic significance of urban music .', "Incorporating insightful dialogue with the participant in this economy , White challenges the prevailing wisdom on marginalised young people , whilst also confronting the assumption that the inertia and localisation of the grime culture result from its close link to NEET `` member '' and the informal sector .", 'Offering an ethnographic and timely critique of the NEET classification , this compelling book would be suitable for undergraduate and post-graduate student interested in urban study , business , work and labour , education and employment , ethnography , music , and cultural study .', 'Beside downtown : Global Chinatowns .', "For much of the nineteenth and twentieth century , in Barcelona 's barrio chino/barrixino , decaying tenement and crowded street housed thousand of immigrant worker slaving in aging factory or seeking day- to- day opportunity at the nearby port .", "Only the broad , tree- lined Rambles , a promenade beloved of flâneurs , separated the middling class and elite of the historic city center from this `` Chinatown '' ( this boulevard , in fact , had replaced an earlier urban wall ) .", 'After dark , however , exotic nocturnal amusement including prostitution , drug , and gambling lured adventurous bourgeois men , bohemian artist , journalist , and even transnational revolutionary into the barrio chino .', "In the twenty- first century , nonetheless , as Barcelona 's post- Olympic urban revitalization has spread from the port and historical core outward , this `` Chinatown , '' rechristened as the historic Raval , has been demolished in favor of neoliberal development of sanitized public space , new hotel and tourist ser vice , gentrified residence , and cultural facility including museum , foundation , and the Universitat de Barcelona .", 'The Raval has displaced the chino , its older inhabitant , its bar , social center and memory ( McDonogh 1987 , 2002 ; McNeill 1999 ; Magrinyà and Maza , this volume ) .', 'While this may seem to be a stereo typical Chinatown in location , function , and imagery , it differs from others where we have worked in a fundamental demographic element- the absence of Chinese .', 'Barcelona had few Chinese until the 1990s .', 'Instead , many inhabitant of this dense central zone had arrived from poorer Spanish region of Andalusia and Aragon .', "Journalist Paco Madrid borrowed the sobriquet `` Chinatown '' in 1927 from his reading of San Francisco , using barrio chino as an urban metaphor to evoke an ambience of cosmopolitan mystery and Barcelona 's status as a world city ( McDonogh 1987 ) .", 'When the first wave of Chinese arrived in Spain in the late 1990s , in fact , they settled elsewhere , including an important cluster next to the downtown area of a suburban Barcelona satellite city , Santa Coloma .', "Nonetheless , Barcelonans ' metaphorization of the early twentieth- century location and imagery of Chinatowns , like the demand and pressure of center city development that continue to change the area , are familiar and even suggestive phenomenon for global downtown .", "For more than a decade we have lived , worked , and studied in Chinatowns worldwide , including Chinese enclave in and around Chicago , New York , Sydney , Lima , Los Angeles , Bangkok , Havana , Paris , San José , Panama City , and São Paulo , in addition to our anchorage in Wong 's native Hong Kong and our home in Greater Philadelphia .", 'These Chinatowns sometimes have been background for other project in urban study , mass medium , architecture , and visual culture ( for example , Wong 1991 , 1999 ) ; they also have become interwoven with life of our family and friend .', 'Our experience and investigation underpin the complexity of multisite downtown ethnography through which we have examined shared characteristic of place , function , ideology , and evolution ( McDonogh and Wong 2005 ) .', 'These social , special , and cultural feature embody both Chinese agency and evolving Chinese globalization , although we do not develop such a phenomenological exploration here .', 'Instead , we argue that Chinatowns are deeply enmeshed with the structure and nature of central district that such Chinatowns often border , a relationship mapped decade ago by Burgess and the Chicago School ( Burgess 1925 : 56 ) .', 'Chinatowns provide a multivalent vantage from which to illuminate critical feature of global downtown , including the evolution of central space and function , the competitive market for people and capital they embody , and the play of locality , region , nation- state , and transnational articulation shaping downtown as well as Chinatowns .', 'To analyze the dialectic of Chinatowns and global downtown , we consider five specific theme : ( 1 ) the emergence and movement of Chinatowns in relation to urban core ; ( 2 ) the imagery of Chinatowns as cultural space that illuminates race , immigration , gender , and morality in downtown ; ( 3 ) competing contemporary demand for land , development , and movement , both Chinese and non- Chinese ; ( 4 ) the meaning of Chinatowns in relation to suburban and global network ; and ( 5 ) new Chinatowns as a counterpoint to future downtown .', 'Together , these theme underscore the fact that Chinatowns are not exotic alternative space but offer fundamental insight on downtown as urban/regional place of political economic power , social structure , and cultural meaning constituted by multilayered and contested global flow of good , people , knowledge , and imagery .', 'A spirit of urban capitalism : market city , people city , and cultural justification .', 'Diverse urban theory discuss how economic process shape conception of a city , but less research focuses on how pragmatic situation of urban life contribute to the characterisation of city .', 'We argue that pragmatic justification reify socially constructed meaning of city by creating a ‘ spirit of urban capitalism.', '’ This framework conceives of two spirit : the market city , which aligns with neoliberal assumption , and the people city , which foregrounds a resident-focused model .', 'Using case study of Copenhagen and Houston , we showcase how these conception of city are justified by elite and resident , and thereby build empirical scaffolding connecting urban economy and culture .', 'Spatial culture : Towards a new social morphology of city past and present .', 'What is the relationship between how city work and what city mean ?', 'Spatial Culture : Towards a New Social Morphology of Cities Past and Present announces an innovative research agenda for urban study in which theme and method from urban history , social theory and built environment research are brought into dialogue across disciplinary and chronological boundary .', 'The collection confronts the recurrent epistemological impasse that arises between research focussing on the description of material built environment and that which is concerned primarily with the people who inhabit , govern and write about city past and present .', 'A reluctance to engage substantively with this issue has been detrimental to scholarly effort to understand the urban built environment as a meaningful agent of human social experience .', 'Drawing on a wide range of historical and contemporary urban case study , as well as a selection of theoretical and methodological reflection , the contribution to this volume seek to historically , geographically and architecturally contextualize diverse spatial practice including movement , encounter , play , procession and neighbourhood .', 'The aim is to challenge their tacit treatment as universal category in much writing on city and to propose alternative research possibility with implication as much for urban design thinking as for history and the social science .', 'Public art in Canada : Critical perspective .', 'Arguably , public art is experienced daily by more people than most offering in gallery , yet our notion of what constitutes public art is surprisingly limited .', "Public Art in Canada broadens the critical discussion by exploring public art 's varied mean of engaging with public space and the public sphere .", 'Annie Gérin and James S. McLean have assembled contribution from new and established Canadian scholar , curator , and artist .', 'Each contributor enlivens our understanding of public art as a practice and its place in the social and aesthetic formation of which it is a part .', 'As a result , the book provides an overview of the current debate in the field of public art that are informed by the theory and critical literature of art history , communication study , cultural study , sociology , and urban study .', 'The rigorous essay and original work of art collected in this volume present a compelling demonstration of the strategy , aesthetic and otherwise , used by artist to elicit intellectual , sensual , or emotional response that can only be obtained through artistic practice in public place .', 'Public Art in Canada is a major contribution to the study of Canadian art and culture .', 'Improvising urban space , inhabiting the in-between .', 'This paper discusses improvisation as a liminal practice of inhabiting the in-between that marks urban space from squat and brownfields to communal garden , from infrastructural maintenance and urban living lab to political protest and solidarity in time of crisis .', 'It shows how improvisation emerges in the interstice between uncertain flux and ossified rigidity to construct in-between space of ambiguous political opening even in ostensibly formal , rigid contexts .', 'To that end , it draws on document , medium report , interview and participant observation to analyse the multiple mutation of what eventually became the Boris Yeltsin Presidential Centre in Ekaterinburg , a cultural flagship in Russia ’ s third largest city .', 'Morphed from an abandoned office block into a memorial multi-purpose complex , the Yeltsin Centre is the product of elite and ordinary people responding to conjunctural opening in seemingly inert structure .', 'While highlighting the political opening made possible by improvisation inhabiting the in-between , the paper also underscores the ambiguous nature of this practice and its limit .', 'On the trail of comparative urbanism : Square dance and public space in China .', 'Civic culture in public space occupy a central place in the theorisation of social relation and social interaction in the modern city .', 'But theoretical perspective formulated in Western urban context tend to assume clear-cut distinction between Gesellschaft and Gemeinschaft , and between the public and private realm , and assume that encounter automatically steers people towards the ethic and politics of difference .', 'These optic represent epistemology which for the most part address the socio-spatial nexus in Euro-American urban modernity , and are ill equipped for elucidating the contingent , improvised relationship between public space and multiple urban modernity beyond the West .', 'This paper works on the trail of the comparative urbanism and delves into configuration of publicness in “ square dance ” in reform-era urban China .', 'Starting from historical conception of publicness in China but being mindful of how they are reconfigured and renegotiated amid a rapid transition towards urban modernity , this paper argues that publicness in reform-era China is of a largely experimental , negotiated nature .', 'On the one hand , square dance exceeds sociological account and category which produce epistemological opposition between stranger and community , between public self and intimate affiliation .', 'It incubates sentiment of collectivism that overcome anonymity and strangeness but do not contradict the ethos of individualism in the modern city .', 'On the other hand , square dance can be conceptualised as an active process of urban learning , in which people are motivated to reflect over what code , rule , and ethic are needed for governing urban public .', 'In all , this paper aims to broaden the conceptual spectrum of the idea of public space and urban civic culture through comparative analysis and theorisation .', 'The information , practice and view in this article are those of the author ( s ) and do not necessarily reflect the opinion of the Royal Geographical Society ( with IBG ) .', 'Decolonial Hip Hop : Indigenous Hip Hop and the disruption of settler colonialism .', 'Contemporary Detroit has gone through many changes–or so it appears .', 'From street lined with vehicle made by Chrysler , Ford , and General Motors and driven by the nearly 2 million people who called the city home in 1950 to certain part of the city looking like ghost town ; from a population that dwindled to 670,000 to the revival of downtown .', 'Yet , what has been remarkably consistent is the invisibility of the Motor City ’ s Indigenous population .', 'Indeed , Indigenous erasure , combined with rhetoric and policy that continue to marginalize and subjugate African Americans in Detroit , create a place rooted in multiple colonialism .', 'This essay examines how Detroit ’ s Indigenous Hip Hop artists resist settler colonialism through art , creativity , and culture as well as the practice of Detroit 2.0 , a rhetoric and policy used by Detroit elites to reimagine it as a place of opportunity .', 'By making visible the connection between blackness and indigeneity , as well as by linking the struggle of colonized people in Detroit to those in Palestine , Indigenous artist are not only asserting their humanity and challenging the longstanding idea of their erasure , but also constructing pathway for artist and activist to disrupt the effect of multiple colonialism that continue to marginalize people of colour in urban area .', 'Detroit ’ s Indigenous Hip Hop artist make socially conscious music and also participate as activist in the city of Detroit .', 'They serve as a window onto contemporary Indigenous identity , represent an exemplar of the urban Indigenous experience , and combine activism with art in a variety of way .', 'Learning to belong ?', '‘ Culture ’ and ‘ place making ’ among child and young people in Hull , UK City of Culture 2017 .', 'Despite the rise of ‘ child-friendly city ’ internationally , and a growing interest in youth engagement in urban planning , the role of child and young people in culture-led regeneration and ‘ place making ’ scheme , remains under-researched .', 'Notwithstanding the wealth of research into childhood and youth culture , little is known about the way in which the abstract ( and perhaps predominantly ‘ adult ’ ) notion of ‘ culture ’ and ‘ place ’ are negotiated by younger citizen .', 'Drawing on participative research with school across Hull , the UK City of Culture 2017 , this contribution explores child ’ s and young people ’ s understanding of culture and place within this cultural regeneration event .', 'Although our finding suggest that the City of Culture designation has brought benefit to child and young people in a marginalised city , there is still much to be learned from their often personal and informal interpretation of ‘ place ’ and ‘ culture ’ , as well as the role played by school in this context .', 'Acropolis now : Ponte City as portrait of a city .', 'Ponte City is a project by Mikhael Subotzky and Patrick Waterhouse that uses photographs , architectural diagram , text , interview , fiction , found object , oral history , and archival material to critically explore a particular urban landscape in Johannesburg .', 'The exhibition and book , which comprise this project , manifest in different way , but both work together to cut across discipline and incorporate the language of fine art , photography , architecture , urban planning , history , economics , popular culture , and literature .', 'The publication comprises a book of photographs and pamphlet in which the artist have collaborated with former and current resident , gathered personal story , delved into the archive , invited author to contribute essay on a variety of topic , and worked with material found at the site .', "This article examines the notion of a 'portrait of a city ' in relation to the Ponte City project , and asks the question : What is a portrait of a city ?", "Is it possible to take a 'portrait of a city ' , and what technique are used when a photographer portrays place and people , or attempt to take , or make , a 'portrait ' - of a city , a place or even a building such as Ponte ?", 'Can a building come to stand in for a city ?', 'And how have these strategy been put into play by Subotzky and Waterhouse in the Ponte City project ?', "Hip Hop Versus Rap : The Politics of Droppin ' Knowledge .", "'What is the real hip hop ? '", "'To whom does hip hop belong ? '", "'For what constructive purpose can hip hop be put to use ? '", "These are three key question posed by hip hop activist in Hip Hop Versus Rap , which explores the politics of cultural authenticity , ownership , and uplift in London 's post-hip hop scene .", "The book is an ethnographic study of the identity , role , formation , and practice of the organic intellectual that populate and propagate this 'conscious ' hip hop milieu .", "Turner provides an insightful examination of the work of artist and practitioner who use hip hop 'off-street ' in the sphere of youth work , education , and theatre to raise consciousness and to develop artistic and personal skill .", 'Hip Hop Versus Rap seeks to portray how cultural activism , which styles itself grassroots and mature , is framed around a discursive opposition between what is authentic and ethical in hip hop culture and what is counterfeit and corrupt .', "Turner identifies that this play of difference , framed as an ethical schism , also presents hip hop 's organic intellectual with a narrative that enables them to align their insurgent value with those of policy and to thereby receive institutional support .", 'This enlightening volume will be of interest to post-graduates and scholar interested in hip hop study ; youth work ; critical pedagogy ; young people and crime/justice ; the politics of race/racism ; the politics of youth/education ; urban governance ; social movement study ; street culture study ; and vernacular study .', 'Hip-hop and the reconfiguration of Blackness in Sao Paulo : the influence of African American political and musical movement in the twentieth century .', 'Hip-hop arrived in São Paulo , Brazil in the late 1970s .', 'During this time , African Brazilians organized meeting known as ‘ Black parties.', '’ At Black party , people listened to music , danced and shared Black experience .', 'The Black party were greatly influenced by African-American music such as soul , funk and jazz , and contemporary socio-political movement like Civil Rights and the Black Panther Party .', 'African Brazilians disseminated image and symbol about blackness and called for Black pride .', "Phrase like James Brown 's ‘ Say It Loud : I 'm Black and I 'm Proud ' were widespread .", 'Today , hip-hop is recognized as an important influence in African-Brazilian history .', 'The cultural exchange between Black youth in São Paulo and New York contributed to the reconfiguration of the Black movement in Brazil and was the vehicle by which African Brazilians acquired knowledge of the African diaspora .', 'This essay will present three important argument for understanding how hip-hop became a great political movement among Black youth in Brazil .', 'My first argument is that African-American culture has provided a political language to what Paul Gilroy calls the ‘ Black universe.', '’ This was accomplished through the public circulation of image and symbol about Black struggle .', 'Secondly , São Paulo and New York , though structurally different , have similar history in the area of urban planning and population growth , and hip-hop had a comparable effect on marginalized community in both city .', 'Finally , the cultural exchange between Black youth of São Paulo and New York helped change the Black movement and identity in São Paulo .', 'The temptation of nationalism in modern capital city .', 'In a world riven by ethnic , racial , and nationalist conflict , there is much appeal to the idea that city might be able to transcend the pressure of their embed-dedness in nation-states , and that an urban-centered identity could rally less destructive sort of allegiance .', "One promising venue for testing such claim is the capital city , since-by definition-such place need to represent the seat of government and other `` national '' institution .", 'At the same time , capital city are not equivalent to nation-states ; they are still separately identifiable as city , even though they are certainly city of a very specialized kind .', "The act of designing a new capital city-or building significant new `` national '' institution in an existing capital city-forces an engagement with question of national representation.1 Specifically , how are multiple social identity constructed through architecture and urban design ?", 'And , if such constructed identity matter , which group in a plural society see themselves as represented in what gets built to represent supposedly national institution ?', 'Does a capital city represent an opportunity to provide an alternative to nationalist discourse and subnational division , or does it serve to reinforce the sense that some people are included in the conception of the nation-state much more so than others ?', 'In this chapter , I attempt to argue three thing : 1 .', "A wide variety of regime have used urban design and architecture to advance a nationalist agenda , and this `` design politics '' operates at all visible scale .", '2 .', 'When such regime give in to the temptation of nationalism , the result are usually very divisive .', '3 .', 'Conversely , it is possible to imagine way that architecture and urban design can be used to heal political rift .', "Ernest Gellner , in his book Nations and Nationalism , defines nationalism as `` a theory of political legitimacy '' which holds that `` the political and the national unit should be congruent '' ( Gellner 1983 , 1 ) .", "In other word , the political unit-what we generally call the nation-state , or more informally the `` country '' -and the national unit should coincide exactly if they are superimposed .", 'The problem is that the world is not organized this way , largely due to a long history of empire and colonialism , not to mention a variety of supranational political and economic alliance .', 'If , as one extreme example demonstrates , one compares a map of Africa subdivided according to the border of nation-states with a map showing the far more fine-grained subdivision of ethnic group that fall both within and across the boundary of many nation-states , the two bear little resemblance and help explain major internal and international tension .', 'It is true that the system of African nation-states is far more equitable than the coarse grain of the imperially divided spoil that characterized the map of the earlier colonized continent , but the legacy of a continent fragmented by the will of European colonist still suffers from the legacy of irrationally imposed border .', 'The modern system of nation-states-built mostly in the last two century ( and especially during the last sixty year , a time when the number of nation-states has more than tripled ) has not been easily superimposed on the system of ethnically defined nation or would-be nation , many of which find themselves to be subdivision ( or minority group within ) a nation-state that they do not recognize as legitimate .', 'In short , the map that depict people do not correspond very well with the map that depict place .', "If one turns to a reputable source like the newest American Heritage Dictionary , which is often serviceable for most purpose ( though even that book 's name seems to raise additional question about this very topic ) , the proffered definition of nationalism seem at least as evasive or incomplete as Gellner 's .", "In the first instance , according to the American Heritage , nationalism denotes `` devotion to the interest or culture of one 's nation . ''", "What is not said , of course , is that `` nation '' in this sense may not exactly coincide with one 's nation-state .", 'In other word , nationalism can often be about devotion to some subnational portion of a pluralist nation-state that is attempting to harness and discipline many constituent nation within it .', "Nationalism can also be counter-posed to internationalism , as when the dictionary defines it as `` the belief that nation will benefit from acting independently rather than collectively , emphasizing national rather than international goal . ''", "Finally , nationalism may denote `` aspiration for national independence in a country under foreign domination . ''", 'This latter aspect seems particularly important , since it implies that nationalism is not necessarily tied to some fixed moment in political history .', "There is a nationalism of aspiration-embraced by those who do not yet control a nation-state but think that they should-as well as a nationalism of consolidation-championed by those who do control a nation-state but are struggling to make sure that the aspiring nation within its border do not succeed in undermining the state 's sovereign legitimacy .", "What I refer to as the `` temptation of nationalism '' in the title of this chapter is largely focused on the latter kind of nationalism .", "For those that are still aspiring to become nation-states , `` the temptation of nationalism '' is no more than an obvious tautology .", 'For nation-states struggling to maintain their political hold on their constituent people ( or to extend their hold onto adjacent territory ) , however , this nationalism of consolidation is both urgent and difficult to construct .', 'Nationalism in this sense is a two-stage proposition : the first stage-the nationalism of aspiration-supports a drive for independence in the name of freedom and self-determination , and the second stage-the nationalism of consolidation-is what is needed to define the self that has been freed .', "As political scientist Crawford Young puts it , the state which , before independence , had been the `` foil against which unity was forged '' is , after independence , `` itself the main vehicle in the hand of the nationalist elite for the fulfillment of the mission '' ( Young 1978 , 71 ) .", 'In other word , nationalist movement begin as struggle against the state but , if they succeed , they suddenly have to become the state , themselves .', 'Because the hold on power is uncertain , the leader of a nation-state are tempted to take nationalistic position that endeavor to suppress or supersede pre-independence subnational identity that are not useful to the dominant group in power .', 'The temptation of nationalism is the promise of unity and legitimacy , the dream of a consolidated nation-state unchallenged by those who would unravel it or secede .', 'Asphalt bandit : Fear , insecurity , and uncertainty in the Latin American city .', "This article looks at the malandro , the bandit of Venezuela 's poor neighborhood , as a paradoxical and hybrid figure of the urban Caribbean , a virtuoso actor of the culture of emergency and Asphalt .", "Threatened by global uncertainty , postcolonial Creole city turn to black Saint from Africa , as well as to creole gangster from the barrio 's backstreets .", 'Malandros are delinquent yet consummate actor of the urban scene .', 'At the turn of the twenty-first century , malandros have been thrown out of the margin to the center of society , becoming simultaneously hero and enemy of the people .', 'Malandros are crafty , but their life are violent and they die young .', 'Yet , they embody the shape of thing to come .', 'If the barrio reflects the violence of postcolonial urbanization , the violence of the malandro reflects , in an inverted image , injustice in a globalized world .', 'These injustice are what we ought to think through and destroy .', 'Ethnic tourism : Who is exotic for whom ?', '.', 'In the last two decade , urban tourism shifted from a heritage-focused supply to a broader offer ( Maitland and Newman 2009 ) .', 'While ‘ traditional ’ urban tourism was concentrated mainly in and around historic city centre , the diversification of urban tourism has integrated new quarter and area previously ignored by visitor .', 'As Hoffman explains ‘ the differentiation of formerly standardized market has valorized multiculturalism and diversity , giving rise to new form of cultural capital and creating interest in formerly unattractive place ’ ( Hoffman 2003b : 92 ) .', 'The underlying idea of such policy was to develop disadvantaged area and regenerate them through the creation of tourism activity ( Zukin 1998 ) , but also to demonstrate how inclusive and cosmopolitan a city can be ( Shaw 2007 ) .', 'These development concerned mainly former industrial area and district with a high rate of migrant shaping a city of quarter ( Roodhouse 2006 ) allowing tourist to choose à la carte according to their interest .', 'Myriad tourism asset could thus be created from art studio over fashion district to ethnic market and , in extreme case , to slum tourism .', 'So-called ‘ ethnic quarter ’ became in many city an interesting asset for tourism authority ( Rath 2007 ) .', 'Chinese quarter , Little Italys or Little Indias were promoted as a means of encountering the exotic .', 'Indeed , ethnic quarter represent enclave with an extensive variety of linguistic , religious , family and friendship entity .', 'On the one hand they play the role of important storehouse of heritage that are often in the process of disappearing in developing ‘ home ’ country abroad ( Smith and Maryann 2001 ) .', 'On the other hand they embody a melting pot of many different culture , composed of local , immigrant , resident and user ( Chang 1999 ) .', 'Many ethnic quarter grew indeed through the settlement of migrant worker in impoverished area with little or no urban planning .', 'However , as soon as the community member could afford to settle in a wealthier area they left the district .', 'What remained were the shop and specialised service provider offering specific cultural good and providing the opportunity of social exchange and contact with other community member .', 'Very important in that context is the food and beverage supply for being often emphasised by the tourism promotion as cluster of exotic restaurant ( Conforti 1996 ; Trevor and Monder 2003 ; Selby 2004 ) .', 'These commercial ethnic belt ( McLaughlin and Jesilow , 1998 ) attract community member , allowing them to distinguish themselves from the host country for a limited time and reafirming their identity ( Diekmann and Maulet 2009 ) .', 'However , the movement of people out of the district exacerbates the already problematic situation ( dilapidated housing , high unemployment and high rate of crime ) of the area .', 'In fact , new migrant from other country settle in the dilapidated area following the same path as their predecessor and generating a multicultural melting pot .', 'Moreover , as highlighted by Hoffman , these area are frequently characterised by a distinct “ ghetto ’ economy , social/spatial isolation and exclusion , negatively perceived culture , political patronage and social policy ( Hoffman 2003b : 105 ) .', 'While Hoffman distinguishes this state as being a Fordist concept , it is indeed in many country valid as long as regeneration has not been considered for the district under scrutiny .', 'One regeneration process is tourism development .', 'Yet , the type of development depends to a large extent on the geographical situation and connection to the main tourism cluster and urban space .', 'The chapter examines the concept of ethnic tourism by highlighting the ambivalence in promoting specific cultural community as exotic to the ‘ tourist community ’ , and in that ‘ excluding ’ a whole group of ( potential ) consumer , that often constitute the majority of visitor .', 'Finding from a recent survey led in the sub-Saharan African precinct Matonge in Brussels will highlight the signi ?', 'cance of community visitor .', 'Moreover , the chapter will look into the promotional policy and how the tourism mediation shapes the community and stakeholder in the development process , focusing on several example .', 'Touring poverty .', 'Touring Poverty addresses a highly controversial practice : the transformation of impoverished neighbourhood into valued attraction for international tourist .', "In the megacities of the Global South , selected and idealized aspect of poverty are being turned into a tourist commodity for consumption.The book takes the reader on a journey through Rocinha , a neighbourhood in Rio de Janeiro which is advertised as `` the largest favela in Latin America '' .", 'Bianca Freire-Medeiros present interview with tour operator , guide , tourist and dweller to explore the vital question raised by this kind of tourism .', 'How and why do diverse social actor and institution orchestrate , perform and consume touristic poverty ?', 'In the context of globalization and neoliberalism , what are the
